Title:
Two forgotten European species resurrected and
phylogenetically confirmed: Pluteus dianae and Pluteus punctatus
(Agaricales, Pluteaceae), and first records of these species from East
and North Europe
Keywords:
Pluteaceae, section Hispidoderma, Pluteus plautus group,
Type studies, Phylogeny, nrITS, Taxonomy
Abstract:
The type collections of two poorly known species, Pluteus
dianae and P. punctatus, were studied morphologically and
phylogenetically using the DNA sequence of ITS region of ribosomal RNA
gene. These two species were described in 1968 (P. dianae) and in 1972
(P. punctatus) based on material collected in the Czech Republic. Now,
for the first time, further collections are identified based on
molecular analysis, and the first findings of these species from East
and North Europe (P. dianae from Denmark and Russia, P. punctatus from
Sweden) are given. Variability of macrocharacters, microcharacters,
ecology and distribution of Pluteus dianae and P. punctatus were
enlarged based on recent findings. The application of both names is
discussed, based on our type studies and additional recent collections.
Both species belong in the Pluteus plautus species complex (Pluteus
sect. Hispidoderma), and based on the data presented here they are
distinct from all other known taxa in this group. European and North
American taxa (data on European taxa?) of P. plautus group are
summarised and compared with Pluteus dianae and P. punctatus.
